text: Bottle at Castle Tap, Reading. 19/05/17. The aroma certainly is creamy. Deep and dark. Thick off-white head. Sweet, with a hint of bitterness. Fake fondant cream sweetness, not my thing. Light. Oily. Very lively carbonation. Short finish. I couldnt finish it. The cream just built up and really put me off.
Bottle from Coppers, Newcastle. Hazy black with a thick white head. It has a chocolate, citrus, pine and whisky flavour with coconut and mint on the roasted, bitter finish. Excellent!

Cask at Craft Beer Co, Brixton, London. A dark brown/black coloured pour with a medium off white head on top. Roasty, malty, dark fruit aroma. Tastes roasty, malty, dark fruit, some sorachi in there. Not bad but seemed rather unbalanced.

Cask at Londinum at Tree Folks, Rome-Italy.coffe break pour, ivory foam. Nose: sweet malt leftovers, almonds blast, almonds milk. Mouth: easy although tasty, a bit metallic and monotone. Nose was better. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

330ml bottle from Good Spirits Co. Wine & Beer. Very dark brown, decent head. Nice bottle artwork. Coffee cheesecake aroma. Spicy creamy treacle coffee flavour. Smooth with spicy aftertaste. Different!
bottle at home .. dark black brown ... thick tan head ... soft bretty funk ... roast malts nose ... dry bretty red wine .. rich roast ... light funk

Bottle from Cotteridge Wines, Birmingham. Poured a almost black with a bubbly off white head. The aroma is yeasty creamy cheese, roasty grassy hop. The flavour is moderate bitter with a crisp roasty big grassy hop, light fruit palate. Medium bodied with average carbonation.

Bottle shared at Cotteridge Wines, Birmingham. Black with a tan head. Aroma of chocolate,
red fruits, cream and toffee. Flavour is moderate sweet and bitter. Medium bodied with soft carbonation.

Bottle from the Good Spirits Co. Wine & Beer. Pours darkest brown with a thick foamy head, settles to generous foam. Not much on the nose initially, but as the foam dies down it becomes creamy, mocha coffee, and sorachi ace. Taste is creamy, roasty malt, rather sweet, brown sugar, also some savoury notes, into a slightly bitter finish. Palate is great - medium+ body, smooth, and clean. A very interesting beer
330ml bottle. Pours caramel brown with a medium head. Aroma is Seville orange, cocoa and herby. Taste has cocoa and orange to start. Herby bubblegum finish. Love Sorachi.
Pours black with a thick creamy head. Aroma is earthy, grassy. An sweet, licorice, treacle earthy flavour.

330ml bottle. Cloudy, black-ish darkest ruby colour with average to huge, creamy, fairly lasting, minimally lacing, off-white head. Grassy, hoppy aroma, earthy nuttily background, notes of walnut. Taste is nuttily malty, notes of walnut, sweetish crème caramel basis, grassy hoppy overtones. Really creamy palate, lasting caramel finish.

27th October 2016Opaque black - brown beer, good pale tan head. Palate is airy and semi dry, decent fine carbonation. Fluffy malts, mellow dark character. Mild roast and dark chocolate. Mild floralness. A light Sorachi lemon kick, floral lemon. Airy finish. Quite fluffy but the Sorachi brings it home.

Bottle from Caps and Taps, London - UK. Color: deep dark black beer with no carbonation and medium creamy brownish head. Smell: roasted malt, grassy and fresh hops notes. Taste: medium body, roasted malt with creamy taste grassy notes and bitterness with fresh hops. Aftertaste: wet bitterness, roasted malt, caramel. Good attenaution. Highly drinkable.

6.5%ABV. Cream ale.

Poured out dark brown. 30ºSRM.

Nose has a thick funky sour cream aroma that could b construed to be cream corn, but this particular iteration is a little thick to be associated with an aroma as light and creamy as creamed corn. I get light sulfur, roasted acorns and light saddle leather. A little creamy finish.

Mouthfeel is waxy and a little oily. Palate is has a foundation of pale malt with some nice bready flavors, maybe bread dough. There is an aggressive bitter that is a little jarring at first, but then starts to make more sense as you continue to sip. Hops are a little spicy, bitter melon, sap, resin, grass with some earthy overtones of wet decaying leaves and forest floor. Cilantro and fennel come through progressively.

Finish is long with a lingering soapy bitter hanging around at the back of the throat. Usually when this happens, a Columbus hop or a similar varietal is in there.

Cask conditioned at The University club, Oxford. Black with cream head. There is a deep bitterness to the malts in this, chewy with a liquorice and chocolate body. Quite dry in the close. Pretty reasonable.
Bottle at home. Pours black colour. Semi sweet taste, lightly fruity, dark malt, earthy. Dry bitter finish. Very tasty :)
Cask @ Friends Of Ham, Leeds. Dark brown with a small creamy head. Has a strength with a defined tropical fruitiness dominating this.

Bottle. Dark with little head. Aroma of wood, cream, mint (bit of an After-Eight thing) and lemon. Similar in taste with some cocoa powder too. Quite a bit of Sorachi going on. Cant say I really know cream ale so not sure how this differs.

Cask. Shakespeares, Sheffield. Clear, dark, cola brown. Thin, sticky, beige head. Nose has scorched citrus. Some dark berries. Earthy malts. Touch of spice. Taste is fruity sweet, turning fairly full, roast malt bitter. Medium body. Soft fizz. Earthy bitter finish. Not for me.

Cask gravity @ 24th Egham Beer Festival. Pours a dark brown black color with a small off-white head. Has a fruity malty caramel aroma. Fruity malty spicy creamy caramel flavor with some bitter hints. Has a fruity malty spicy creamy caramel finish.

Bottle from Bottle Baron. Dark brown body with a medium cream head. Good lacing. Aroma of dark chocolate, rubber, cocoa powder, cat litter and plum. Flavour of ash, cranberry, peanut shell and toasted sesame seeds. Medium body with a creamy texture. Soft fizz. Unusual and challenging. Might have been nicer with different hops.

Dark ruby-brown color, small beige head. Aroma has toasted maltyness, difficult to describe... malt vinegar. Medium-bodied. Somewhat toasted front leading to long bitter aftertaste. Weird beer.

Cask at Egham Beer Festival 24. Reminiscent of a cross between stout & BIPA. 
Smooth creamy texture turns sharply burnt-bitter, swamped by astringent dryness. Great concept that didnt quite gel.

Dark, toasted malts, coffee, dry cacao, light Sorachi Ace, subtle, creamy sweets. Very dark brown, medium, frothy, beige head. Light bitter. More dark, toasted malts, filter coffee, sweet bread and caramel, creamy texture, slightly harsh, bitter and dry finish. Interesting take on a dark Cream Ale, wouldnt want to drink this every day, but not bad indeed. Bottle from brewery, Hanwell.

Bottle at Bottle Shop. It pours black with a decent beige head. The aroma is soft, sweet, creamy, cream soda, white sugar, liquorice, sorachi aniseed, toasted malt. The taste is smooth, dry, bitter, roasted malt, charred, coffee grounds, burnt tires, aniseed and fennel with a dry, charred finish. Medium body and moderate, foamy carbonation. Aroma is quite nice, but the taste is pretty harsh. Fun to try, but ultimately not so drinkable.
UPDATED: JUL 16, 2016 -small sample- black with white head. Barrel, cherries and coffee. Light acidic, short and roasty finish. Lacks body and taste. Great aroma!

On tap at Anspach & Hobday Bermondsey. Dark brown black beer lasting cream head. i mean its a mild but with a sorachi ace finish. I like the sorachi ace part not sure on rest of the beer abd tgat the hop goes with the rest of tge beer. Ends up dry and minty. Odd. Some light chocolate cocoa powder. Mint and pineapple. Odd. Wouldnt drink again dont think the hop works with rest of the beer.

Keg at the brewery. A ruby red mahogany brown coloured pour with a lasting beige head. Aroma is nutty, brown bread, rum and raisin, earthy woody roast, little grape. Flavour is composed of dry woody, toasted grains, hint of vanilla oak. Palate is rounded and slightly creamy with a dry finish. Slightly astringent. Assertive back of the throat bitterness. Good.
Pours dark brown to black with low tan head. Aroma of chocolate, vanilla, light cream. Taste is mild roasty with a chocolate bitter finish. Light and smooth body with average carbonation.
Keg at Bermondsey. Dark brown. Nose is grass, citrus, earthy notes. Tastes citrus hops, creamy, pine, grass, bitter.

Bottle from Cotteridge Wines; dark brown pour with a creamy tan head, aroma has dark berries and canned cream, taste has a hint of dandelion and burdock, dark berries, some liquorice, bitter coffee, with a creamy finish.

Keg at A&H taproom. Pours deep, clear brown with a creamy, khaki head. A handful of toasted grains in the aroma, earth, dirty and aged berries. Light sweet flavour with impressions of cocoa, more toasty malts, earthy bitterness, slight orange peel, burnt toffee. Light to medium bodied with massaging carbonation. Finishes with sturdy burnt grass bitterness, more mellow cocoa, earth. Not bad overall.

Keg at Anspach & Hobday, 02/07/16.
Extremely dark mahogany brown with a well appointed beige covering that retains well.
Nose is big on Sorachi, black pepper, light malt, red berry fruit, toffee, spice.
Taste comprises more punch Sorachi licks, red berry must, slight tarte fruit twang, earthy, grain, light charr.
Medium bodied, smooth massaging carbonation, semi drying close.
Decent for style, interesting Sorachi twist on an otherwise formulaic genre.
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: Keg at the brewery tap room, London. It pours a dark brown color with a small beige head. Aroma is sweet musty and fruity with notes of red berries, apricots, biscuit and light roasted malt. Taste is drier and heavier on the roasted malt notes with some grains, earth, dried leaves, honey melon and papaya. Medium bodied with good carbonation. Overall, tasty
